intro: Quaqua parviflora subsp. swanepoelii, commonly known as the Swanepoel's small-flowered quathl, is a rare and striking member of the Mesembryanthemaceae family. It is native to South Africa, specifically the Western Cape region, where it thrives in rocky, well-drained soils. The plant is characterized by its compact, succulent growth habit and small, star-shaped flowers that range in color from white to pale pink. It blooms during the winter months, adding a delicate beauty to its arid habitat. Due to its limited distribution and specific ecological requirements, it is considered a threatened species.
